newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's development bank to increase lending.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's development bank to increase lending.

text.p: Hungary's state-owned development bank Magyar Fejlesztesi Bank Rt (MFB) said on Thursday it planned further expansion in 1997 by boosting its lendings in its core business of economic development.
"We wish to concentrate on projects which aim to stimulate the economy," Andras Huszty, MFB's CEO told a news conference following MFB's annual general meeting.

The bank plans to increase its pre-tax profit to between 3.1 billion to 3.2 billion forints from 2.76 billion in 1996, and sees its lendings rising to above 50 billion forints from 21 billion, Huszty said.
MFB aims at increasing its balance sheet total to 160 billion forints from 91.9 billion.
Huszty said the bank began on Thursday the process of merging one of its subsidiary banks Corvinbank Rt into another, Konzumbank Rt, to raise its competitiveness.
"We think this restructuring makes it possible to create a bank which has a good position on the money markets in terms of clients, capital and services," Huszty said.
Corvinbank is specialised in financing developing competitive entrepreneurs and in factoring, while Konzumbank is a commercial bank, also serving retail clients.

MFB, which until the end of 1996 was called Hungarian Investment and Development Bank (MBFB), is Hungary's only development bank, ranking ninth in 1996 in terms of pre-tax and after-tax profits, and 12th in terms of balance sheet total, among banks, it said in a statement.
The MFB group, which also includes a securities house and regional development companies, offers businesses medium- and long-term loans, collects claims, and turns around companies for resale.
